title: Proteomic characterization of the interactions between fish serum proteins and waterborne bacteria reveals the suppression of antioxidative defense as a serum-mediated antimicrobial mechanism
abstract: Fish blood is one of the crucial tissues of innate immune system, but the full repertoire of fish serum components involved in antibacterial defense is not fully identified. In this study, we demonstrated that turbot serum, but not the heat-inactivated control, significantly reduced the number of Edwardsiella tarda (E. tarda). By conjugating serum proteins with fluorescent dyes, we showed that E. tarda were coated with multiple fish proteins. In order to identify these proteins, we used E. tarda to capture turbot serum proteins and subjected the samples to shotgun proteomic analysis. A total of 76 fish proteins were identified in high confidence, including known antimicrobial proteins such as immunoglobins and complement components. 34 proteins with no previously known immunological functions were also identified. The expression of one of these proteins, IQ motif containing H (IQCH), was exclusively in fish brain and gonads and was induced during bacterial infection. This approach also allowed the study of the corresponding proteomic changes in E. tarda exposed to turbot serum, which is a general decrease of bacterial protein expression except for an upregulation of membrane components after serum treatment. Interestingly, while most other known stresses stimulate bacterial antioxidant enzymes, fish serum induced a rapid suppression of antioxidant proteins and led to an accumulation of reactive oxygen species. Heat treatment of fish serum eliminated this effect, suggesting that heat labile factors in the fish serum overrode bacterial antioxidant defenses. Taken together, this work offers a comprehensive view of the interactions between fish serum proteins and bacteria, and reveals previously unknown factors and mechanisms in fish innate immunity.

body_text.text: Fishery is one of the fastest growing food-producing industries and provides nearly 50% of all culinary fish [1] . Fish diseases caused by bacterial infection poise a significant threat to the economy and human health [2] . A better understanding of the host defense mechanisms will improve the treatment and prevention of these diseases, and may inspire the development of new antibacterial therapeutics [3] . Unlike high vertebrates, fish rely on their innate immune system as the main line of defense [4] . Fish usually get injured by rubbing on rocks and coral, and during capturing and shipping. This kind of injuries can increase the potential entry of pathogens [5, 6] , which trigger the host defense via antibacterial peptides and proteins. In fish innate immunity, the skin and gill are generally regarded as the first line of defense against pathogens because of the anatomical location of these organs. Blood also contains antibacterial peptides and proteins which are indispensable in early innate immune response [4] . These factors in fish serum include lysozyme, lectins, pentraxins and complement components [7, 8] . Previous studies reported that antimicrobial proteins and peptides like lysozyme and lectins can kill bacteria by inducing pore formation [7] . However, pore formation is not the only mechanism of bacteria killing [9, 10] . Immune proteins can enter bacterial cells and bind to intracellular targets, resulting in the inhibition of molecular synthesis and enzymatic activities linked to cell wall integrity [11, 12] . Some studies reported that the cytotoxicity is caused by the simultaneous depletion of intracellular thiols and induction of metal concentrations, resulting in an oxidative stress [13] . However, the molecular origins of these responses in serum-treated bacteria are not clear. As there has not been a systematic characterization of the interactions between fish serum components and bacteria, the molecular mechanism of serum-mediated bacterial killing is not fully understood.

Marine fish, as exemplified in Medaka (Oryzias melastigma), typically contain more than 1800 proteins involved in innate immunity. The functions of these proteins were postulated mainly based on the homology of their nucleotide sequences with known mammalian immune proteins [14] . Further evidence on the antibacterial roles of these proteins is often limited to their enhanced expression after bacterial challenge [15e17] . However, these techniques seldom led to the discovery of previously unknown immune proteins. Recently, proteomic techniques have been applied to discover bacteria-binding serum proteins, which are likely to be functionally related to antibacterial activities. For example, a proteomic approach was used to identify human plasma factors that bind to Streptococcus pyogenes [18] . By combining a similar affinity-based approach with subcellular fractionation, interactions between shrimp serum proteins and the outer membrane of Vibrio parahaemolyticus were characterized [19] . However, this approach is still relatively rare and has not been applied to fish.

In this study, we aim to bridge this knowledge gap by providing the first large-scale systematic characterization of the binding of fish serum proteins to waterborne pathogenic bacteria. We achieved this by using live bacteria for the affinity purification of the bacteria-binding proteins in fish serum. We used Edwardsiella tarda (E. tarda) as the model bacteria, as it is a causative agent of the loss of many economically important fish crops [20] . The biochemical approach used in this study requires relatively large volumes of fish serum, which necessitates the use of fish with a large body size and genome data. Hence, turbot (Scophthalmus maximus), a commercially valuable marine species known to be affected by E. tarda, was used as the fish model in this work [16] .

The use of live bacteria in this approach also enabled the parallel detection of proteomic changes within the bacteria when exposed to these serum factors. The complement system in animal sera is known to kill bacteria via assembly of the Membrane Attack Complex (MAC) on bacterial cell wall. While the molecular mechanism of MAC formation is well studied, the biochemical and physiological consequences in the bacteria in the wake of MAC assembly are poorly understood [10] . Furthermore, most studies have focused on the impacts of purified preparations of complement components or cytotoxic compounds, and the combined effects of the whole serum on the protein expression of bacteria are seldom addressed. This research gap triggered us to investigate the effect of serum treatment on bacteria. The use of live E. tarda bacteria to affinity purify bacteria-binding serum proteins allowed us to examine the change in the bacterial proteome, from the same MS data, during the initial phase of serum exposure. The results of this study provide a unique molecular overview of the interplay between the fish innate immune proteins and the bacterial proteome.

To investigate the effect of fish serum on waterborne pathogenic bacteria, we observed the viability of three species of bacteria (Edwardsiella tarda, Aeromonas hydrophila and Vibrio alginolyticus) treated with freshly collected turbot serum for 120 min. As shown in Fig. 1A , turbot serum shows an antibacterial effect on all three species. Heat inactivation significantly reduced, but did not completely abolish, the cytotoxicity of turbot serum. We further tested the temporal effect of turbot serum on E. tarda (Fig. 1B) . The number of E. tarda cells steadily decreased over time, reaching about 40% of the starting cell number after 4 h of incubation. Interestingly, heat inactivated serum suppressed the growth in bacterial population but did not induce a decrease in cell number. This suggests that turbot serum possessed heat labile factors that can kill bacteria, while heat resistant factors in the serum can block bacterial proliferation. This observation is consistent with previous studies [21, 22] . We confirmed the cell-killing effect of turbot serum by using a fluorescent viability dye (Fig. 1C ). Scanning electron microscopy indicated that E. tarda treated with turbot serum, but not those treated with culture medium and heat-inactivated serum, developed pores on their cell walls ( Fig. 1D ).
body_text.section: Antibacterial activity of turbot serum on E. tarda

body_text.text: As most antibacterial proteins exert their activities by binding to bacterial cells, we asked whether intact E. tarda cells could be used to affinity-purify the antimicrobial proteins from turbot serum. We performed two-dimensional gel electrophoresis (2DGE) on turbot serum, E. tarda cells and serum-treated E. tarda (Fig. 2AeC) . When compared to untreated bacteria (Fig. 2B ), the 2D gel of serumtreated bacteria (Fig. 2C ) contained a large number of additional protein spots, presumably from the binding of turbot serum proteins to the bacteria. None of these additional protein spots corresponded to the abundant proteins in the 2D gel of crude turbot serum ( Fig. 2A ), suggesting that the bacteria-binding proteins represent a specific subset of proteins in the serum, rather than just the adhesion of abundant serum proteins in bacterial surface. To confirm that these proteins originated from fish serum and were not a result of the up-regulation of endogenous bacterial proteins, we covalently conjugated turbot serum proteins with a fluorescent dye and used the labeled proteins to treat bacteria. As shown in Fig. 2D , E. tarda incubated with the labeled serum were fluorescently decorated, suggesting the binding of serum proteins to the bacterial cells. A gel electrophoretic analysis of the treated cells ( Fig. 2E ) indicated the presence of multiple fluorescent protein species associated with the serum incubated E. tarda. Taken together, these data indicate the presence of a large number of bacteria binding proteins in turbot serum, and live E. tarda cells can be used to affinity-purify these proteins.
body_text.section: Binding of fish serum proteins to E. tarda cells

body_text.text: We next adopted mass spectrometry (MS)-based proteomics to systematically identify the affinity-purified turbot serum proteins. E. tarda cells with incubated with turbot serum. After rinsing away the unbound proteins, the entire serum-bacteria complex was lysed, and the released proteins were processed for MS analysis. MS/MS peak lists were interrogated against an in-house combined database that contains turbot and E. tarda genomes, which allows the identification of proteins from both species in the sample. A total of 228 turbot proteins were identified in at least one of the three technical repeats. After excluding fish proteins that were identified in only one of the repeats from further analyses, we obtained a list of 76 proteins (Table S1 ) that we define as bacteriabinding proteins in turbot serum. Western blotting confirmed the binding of one of these proteins, ceruloplasmin, to E. tarda cells (Fig. S2) . A gene ontology analysis reveals that 47 (62%) of these proteins have known immune-related functions, including eight complement components, three immunoglobulins and seven coagulation factors (Fig. 3A) . The detection of these proteins confirms the validity of our experimental approach. The remaining 29 proteins have no previously known immune or antimicrobial functions. These proteins are mainly involved in translation, DNA repair and metal binding (Fig. 3A) . Among these non-immune proteins, 49% are classified as serum or secreted proteins, consistent with the serum origin of the sample (Fig. 3B) . The identified bacteria-binding proteins do not significantly differ in size and charge from the general turbot proteome ( Fig. 3C ), suggesting that their binding to E. tarda cells were not likely associated with physical properties such as size or electrostatic characteristics. Fig. 3D and E shows the known interactions among the human orthologues of the identified proteins. 35% of the orthologues are known bacteria-binding proteins. The largest protein complex bound to E. tarda is involved in wound healing (Fig. 3E ). Two other complexes, for complement activation and oxygen transport, were also identified ( Fig. 3C and D) . 48% of the detected proteins do not have known interaction partners, possibly because these proteins are relatively less well-characterized. Our study thus allows the generation of hypotheses for the further investigations of these proteins.
body_text.section: Proteomic analysis of E. tarda-binding proteins in fish serum

body_text.text: As a proof of concept, we selected one of the identified bacteriabinding proteins with no known immune function for further characterization. IQCH protein is a fish homologue of the human testis-specific NYD-SP5 protein [23] and contains the IQ (calmodulin-binding) motif. We confirmed that the expression of IQCH is highly tissue-specific in zebrafish, restricted to brain, testis and ovary ( Fig. 4A ). Our proteomic data indicated that IQCH in turbot bound to E. tarda cells and implicated a function of this protein in bacterial infection. To ask whether the expression of this protein is increased during bacterial infection, we injected medaka with E. Tarda bacteria and detected IQCH RNA in the testis 12, 24 and 48 h later. As shown in Fig. 4B , there was a surge of IQCH expression that peaked at 24 h. This is consistent with a possible role in antibacterial defense suggested by our proteomic data.
body_text.section: IQ motif containing H (IQCH) protein is a tissue-specific factor induced by bacterial infection

body_text.text: We performed proteomic analyses on turbot serum treated E. tarda, in triplicate, for different durations (5, 30, 60, 90, 120 min). The abundance of the peptide signals in the serum-treated bacteria was compared to those in the untreated control at each time points, revealed that the number of differentially expressed proteins progressively increased over time (164e384 from 5 to 120 min, Table S2 ). Most of the differentially expressed proteins were downregulated after 30 min of serum treatment (Fig. 5A ), indicating a general shutdown in protein expression when E. tarda bacteria were exposed to fish serum. Ribosomal proteins and proteins involved in energy metabolism underwent a rapid decline, in consistent with the proteomic changes demonstrated by E. coli subjected to growth inhibition [24] . However, unlike nutrientrestricted bacteria, serum-treated E. tarda exhibited a rapid and significant increase in the expression of proteins involved in outer membrane protein assembly and protein transport.
body_text.section: Fish serum treatment leads to bacterial proteomic responses distinct from other stresses

body_text.text: We compared the protein expression profile of E. tarda after turbot serum treatment with other proteomic studies on the response of gram-negative bacteria to stress conditions or chemical toxins (Fig. 5B ). While these studies also showed a general decrease of protein expression in bacteria, some pathways are selectively induced, e.g., fatty acid metabolism, anti-oxidation and carbohydrate synthesis. This suggests the existence of some active responses by the bacteria against the stresses. Our data, however, indicate that these pathways were suppressed by turbot serum. Hence, the combined activities of the components in turbot serum led to a proteomic consequence in bacteria that is distinct from all the previously studied growth-inhibitory factors. In particular, proteins involved in antioxidant defense were strongly reduced as early as 5 min after serum treatment (Fig. 5C ). For example, the abundance of a peptide derived from catalase, one of the major ROS scavengers in bacteria [25] , was significantly reduced after turbot serum incubation ( Fig. 5D and E).
body_text.section: Fish serum treatment leads to bacterial proteomic responses distinct from other stresses

body_text.text: We further characterized the RNA level ( Fig. 6A ) and activity ( Fig. 6B ) of catalase in serum-treated E. tarda and confirmed the suppression of this enzyme at gene expression and functional levels. Interestingly, the effect of serum on the expression level of catalase was eliminated by a prior heating of the serum at 56 C for 30 min, suggesting that the suppression of catalase expression was mediated by heat labile, possibly protein factors. The suppression of ROS scavengers may lead to an accumulation of intracellular ROS in serum-treated bacteria. As shown in Fig. 6C , turbot serum was found to induce more ROS in bacteria. The level of ROS in serumtreated bacteria was even higher than in bacteria treated with 5 mM H 2 O 2 . This result indicates that turbot serum can induce endogenous ROS. Taken together, we demonstrated that exposure of turbot serum caused a suppression of catalase in E. tarda bacteria at RNA, protein and functional levels, probably contributing to the accumulation of ROS in serum-treated bacteria.
body_text.section: Turbot serum suppresses bacterial antioxidant proteins and leads to ROS accumulation

body_text.text: In this study, we have characterized host-pathogen interactions by identifying both the bacteria-binding proteins in fish serum and the change in the bacterial proteome in response to serum treatment. This was made possible by a simple, single-pot approach of capturing bacteria-binding serum proteins by using live bacteria cells. We have identified 76 bacteria-binding proteins in turbot serum with high confidence. More than 60% of them are known bacteria-binding proteins, such as apolipoprotein E, blood clotting factors like coagulation factors and fibrinogens, oxygen transport related proteins like hemoglobin, and complement component proteins (highlighted in Table S1 ). We have confirmed that complement components constitute the largest group of bacteriabinding serum proteins in fish. Other bactericidal proteins, such as lysozyme [26] , were also identified in our experiments. In addition, our data on the binding of coagulating factors to E. tarda (Fig. 3 ) confirm the use of plasminogen, together with treptokinase and fibrinogen, by bacteria to neutralize the actions of complement factors [27] . Our data also show the interaction of transferrin, hemopexin and hemoglobin with E. tarda, a process used by bacteria to scavenge iron through the capture of iron-containing proteins [28e30]. These identified bacteria-binding proteins are consistent with known antibacterial mechanisms and bacterial evasion tactics.

Apart from the validation of known bacteria-binding properties of plasma proteins, our data also provide the experimental basis for the further characterization of other, less well-known immune proteins (Table S1 ). For example, although the immune functions of warm temperature acclimation related 65 kDa protein (Wap65-2) have been proposed based on circumstantial evidence [31] , our data show for the first time its binding to bacteria cells, either directly or in complex with other proteins. In addition, we identified a number of serum proteins with no previous indication of immune-related functions or bacteria-binding properties (Table S1 ). Our data, therefore, can be viewed as a shortlist of proteins potentially acts as factors important in host-bacteria interactions in fish. For example, we demonstrated that IQCH protein, a highly tissue-specific protein induced by bacterial infection, was present in fish serum and could bind to bacteria. Future investigations will confirm the interactions of IQCH protein, as well as other bacteria-binding serum proteins discovered in this study, with E. tarda by Western blotting and by using recombinant proteins. The functional roles of these unknown proteins in the innate immunity of fish should be addressed.

Our proteomic approach has allowed us to characterize the biochemical consequences of turbot serum treatment in E. tarda. We reported the identification and quantitation of 164, 251, 291, 277 and 384 bacterial proteins relatively from five time points (5, 30, 60, 90, 120 min) after serum treatment. As far as we know, this is the largest proteomic study of the effect of animal serum on bacteria. Although our shotgun approach limited the number of proteins that could be measured across time points, we neverthesless were able to analyze the kinetics of more than 200 bacterial proteins in response to Turbot serum (Table S2) . Although the proteomic approach has been applied on gram-negative bacteria exposed to other stresses, these studies generally focused on the impact of single, isolated factors on the bacterial proteome. Fish serum is a complex mixture of molecules, in which at least 76 proteins interact with the bacteria. Here, we showed that the proteomic signature of E. Tarda in response to whole serum treatment was distinct from other previously studied environmental stresses or cytotoxic agents. This possibly represents the combined effects of the multiple serum factors on the bacteria. For example, our observation of the induction of outer membrane proteins after turbot sera treatment is consistent with their role of sequestering complement C4b protein for immune evasion [32] . The upregulation of membrane components in bacteria has also been observed after antibiotic treatment. However, unlike other stresses, fish serum appeared to induce a rapid and general shutdown of all proteins apart from outer membrane proteins.

A recent study has reported that mammalian peptidoglycan recognition proteins (PGRPs), a family of evolutionary conserved antibacterial innate immunity proteins [41] , can bind to the outer membrane of E. coli [42] and induce intracellular ROS and metal concentrations [13] . These findings give us a hint to the bactericidal mechanism of turbot serum proteins. In our data, serum proteins elicited a very strong inhibition on the bacteria antioxidant system (Fig. 4) . Bacteria defend against oxidative stresses by the thioredoxin system that includes thioredoxin, thioredoxin reductase, and NADPH [33] and by TCA cycle intermediates such as isocitrate dehydrogenase and phosphoglyceromutase [34] . While these factors provide a constitutive protection, peroxide scavengers like catalase and alkyl hydroperoxide reductase (Ahpc) [35] are rapidly induced by stresses [36] . Unlike other ROS products, H 2 O 2 is more stable and can diffuse across bacterial membranes and causes more widespread damages in the cells [13] . In particular, catalases is predominant at coping with a high concentration (millimolar) or a sudden burst of H 2 O 2 because they do not require reductants like NADH, which is necessary for AphC [25, 37] . While other stresses stimulate the expression of calatase, our data show that fish serum caused a rapid and dramatic reduction of catalase expression and activity, resulting in a significant accumulation of ROS in E. tarda. As catalase is the primary detoxifier of H 2 O 2 [38] , our data suggest that heat labile factors in the serum of fish, and possibly in other animals, can specifically suppress the antioxidants in bacteria and sensitize bacteria to ROS [39] . Our proteomic data also show that Fe-S cluster proteins were reduced, in accordance with previous studies that H 2 O 2 can damage Fe-S cluster proteins by converting stable Fe-S to an unstable [4Fee4S] 3þ [40] . Through this pathway, ferryl radical ([FeO] 2þ ) can be created and decay into hydroxyl radical (HO ), which can further damage DNA, proteins, and lipids synthesis, resulting in cell death [41] .

In summary, our proteomic analyses on host-bacterial interactions revealed novel factors in the antibacterial actions of fish serum, and elucidated previously unknown bactericidal mechanisms. Future studies will be focused on the identification of heat labile factors in fish serum that mediate the suppression of antioxidant defenses in bacteria. This knowledge will increase our understanding of the fish innate immunity against waterborne microorganisms.

body_text.section: Fish sera isolation and species identification

body_text.text: One ml of bacteria (at 5 Â 10 9 CFU/ml) was separately mixed with 9 ml of heat-treated (56 C, 30 min) or untreated sera and BHI. Initial bacteria numbers were measured. After incubating at room temperature for 2 h, the number of surviving bacteria was counted again using cell counting chamber. The results were expressed as the ratio of bacteria number in each experimental group relative to that of the initial values. In some experiments, E. tarda survival rate during 4 h incubation (counted every 30 min) with or without serum was determined as described previously. Three replicates were used per experiment. In some experiments, the bacteria were labeled by the LIVE/DEAD ® BacLight Bacterial Viability Kits (molecular probes, Invitrogen Detection Technologies) according to the manufacturer's instructions. Images were taken under a confocal microscope (Leica SPE). 2) for 24 h at 4 C. The cells were then washed in 0.1 M, 0.05 M and 0.025 M of PBS for 10 min each. Samples were then dehydrated through a graded ethanol series of 30, 50, 70, 80 and 95% v/v for 10 min each, washed thrice with 100% ethanol for 10 min each and with acetone twice for 15 min each. With the use of carbon tape, the samples were mounted on aluminium stubs. Sputter coating was performed using gold before imaging. The coated samples were observed under a XL30 ESEMFEG environmental scanning electron microscope (Philips Electronics, Netherlands, Europe).

For two-dimensional gel electrophoresis, 48 mg of bacterial lysate or turbot serum was mixed with (IPG) rehydration buffer (8 M urea, 2% (w/v) CHAPS, 0.5% (v/v) immobilized pH gradient (IPG) buffer, 0.002% bormophenol blue and 18 mM DTT) and loaded onto a 7 cm Iso-Electric Focusing (IEF) strip (pH 4e7, GE Healthcare). The proteins were allowed to rehydrate overnight at room temperature and then separated in the first dimension of gel electrophoresis by using a commercial flatbed electrophoresis system (GE Healthcare Ettan IPGphor III, Freiburg, Germany), The samples on the pH 4e7 linear strips begins with a relatively low voltage (300 v, 0.5 h), and second round strips go through a gradient running (1000 v, 0.5 h; 5000 v, 1.5 h). In the last step, strips run at 5000 V for half an hour. After the isoelectric focusing, the IPG strips were treated with 2% (w/v) SDS, 6 M urea, 29.3% (v/v) glycerol, 1.5 M Tris-HCl (pH 8.8), 0.002% bromophenol blue and alkylation followed by 50 mM iodoacetamide (IAA) for 15 min and then placing the strip on 12% (w/v) acrylamide gel for the second dimension of gel electrophoresis. The gels were stained with Coomassie blue and a quantitative analysis of spot intensity from 2DE was performed by using an image analysis software (Nonlinear Dynamics Progenesis SameSpots version 2.3).

Turbot serum was diluted with HBSS (pH 7.4) and labeled by Amersham CyDye DIGE Fluor Cy5 (minimal dye) (GE Healthcare, code No. 28-9345-33) for 30 min on ice in the dark. The reaction was quenched by 10 mM lysine for 10 min. After labeling, fluorescently conjugated serum was used to incubate bacteria for 2 h. To remove unbound proteins multiple washing with HBSS (pH7.4) was performed (10,000 g, 2 min). Pellets were then lysed in 7 M Urea, 2 M Thiourea, 4% (w/v) CHAPS, 2% (v/v) IPG Buffer and 40 mM DTT and sonicated (4 min, 70% amplification). The proteins concentration of E. tarda was measured with a colorimetric assay based on the Bradford method (Thermo Scientific, Rockford, IL. USA). 40 mg of bacteria proteins were separated by sodium dodecyl sulfate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. The gel was first scanned with a scanner (Fujifilm FLA-9000) and post-stained with Coomassie blue (Serva 17525). Values are expressed as mean ± SD (n ¼ 3). ** denotes statistically significant differences (P < 0.01) with respect to the control group. (B) Catalase activity in bacteria treated with or without serum for 60 min. One unit (U) of catalase was defined as the amount of enzyme that decomposed 1 mmol of H 2 O 2 per minute under the assay conditions at 520 nm. (C) E. tarda was incubated with culture medium (BHI), 5 mM H2O2 and turbot serum (TS) for 30 and 60 min. 10 mM DCFH-DA was added in each group after multiple washing with PBS.

body_text.text: Images were taken under a fluorescent microscope with excitation 480 nm and emission 520 nm.

body_text.text: 10 mg lysates from treated or untreated bacteria prepared as described above were separated in 12% SDS polyacrylamide gel and transferred to nitrocellulose membranes (Pall corporation, Pensacola, FL, USA Lot: T02465) by using the XCell Surelock minicell blotting module (Invitrogen), following the manufacturer's instructions. In brief, anti-Ceroloplasmin (Cat No: 5723, AnaSpec, Fremont, CA, USA) was used as the primary antibody with a dilution of 1:500 in 5% milk. The blot was followed incubated in 1:2000 secondary antibodies in 5% milk. The antibodies were detected by using enhanced chemilumi-nescence (Western Bright ECL, Advansta, California, USA) horseradish peroxidase (HRP)-based assays and the signal captured by LAS 4000 chemiluminescent imager (Fuji).

Bacteria with or without turbot serum treatment (for 5, 30, 60, 90 or 120 min) were washed and lysed in 8 M urea for 2 h as described above. The lysate was reduced in 10 mM DTT in 50 mM ammonium bicarbonate (30 min at room temperature) and alkylated in 50 mM IAA in 50 mM ammonium bio-carbonate (20 min at room temperature). The samples were diluted with ammonium bicarbonate (50 mM, pH 8.0) so that the final concentration of urea was 1 M, followed by 2 mg trypsin (Roche, Mannheim, Germany) digestion. The mixtures were then incubated overnight at 37 C and dried in a vacuum centrifuge (Eppendorf concentrator plus). Peptides were dissolved in 20 ml 0.1% trifluoroacetic acid (TFA), followed by ZipTip (Millipore, Billerica, MA, USA) purification according to the manufacturer's instruction.

All mass spectrometry data were collected on an Orbitrap Fusion Mass Spectrometer (MS) (ThermoFisher Scientific™, San Jose, CA) coupled to a Proxeon EASY-nLC liquid chromatography (LC) pump (ThermoFisher Scientific™). Peptides were eluted using microcapillary column 50 cm Â 75 mm ID, PepMap C18, 2 mm of particles (ThermoFisher Scientific™). The peptides were separated by using 2 h gradient of 2e90% acetonitrile in 0.1% formic acid at a flow rate of~350 nL/min. They were ionized by electrospray ionization by applying a positive 2.5 kV potential to a laser pulled spray tip at the end of the analytical column. Survey scans of peptide precursors from 350 to 1550 m/z were performed at 120 K resolution at 200 m/ z. Tandem MS was performed by isolation at 1.2 Th with the quadrupole, CID fragmentation with normalized collision energy of 35%, and rapid scan MS analysis in the ion trap. The MS2 ion count target was set to 104 and the max injection time was 250 ms only those precursors with charge state 2e7 were fragmented for MS2. The dynamic exclusion duration was set to 60 s with a 10 ppm of low and high mass tolerance around the selected precursor and its isotopes. The instrument was run in top speed mode with 3 s cycles, meaning the instrument would continuously perform MS2 events until the list of non excluded precursors diminishes to zero or 3 s, whichever is shorter and the data dependent top 20 precursors were selected for MS2.

The MS/MS peak lists were exported as an .mgf file, and proteins were identified via automated Mascot database searching (Matrix Science 2.2.04) of all tandem mass spectra against of a custom made database containing flounder fish and E. tarda genomes (72762 sequences, NCBI). The instrument setting for the Mascot search was specified as "ESI-FTICR." Parameters used for the database search were as follows: a maximum of two miss cleavages; carbamidomethyl-ation of cysteine as a fixed modification and oxidation of methionine as variable modifications; trypsin as the enzyme; a peptide mass tolerance of 10 ppm; a fragment mass tolerance of 0.2 Da; and an ion score of 29 as the cut off, using a significance threshold of p < 0.05. After peptide identification, any peptides that had conflicting assignments were resolved, either one of identical proteins or by assignment to proteins with the largest number of peptides already present (by following Occam's Razor principle).

Peptide quantitation was processed by using Progenesis LC-MS (version 4.1, Nonlinear) and as previously described [46] . Briefly, the profile data of two sample groups with triplicates for each were converted to MS features. After "Automatic Alignment", all features with charge ranged from þ2 to þ7 were subjected to normalization. Following a statistical analysis was processed by using transformed "log-like" arcsin (ANOVA) calculations of all the detected features. The total cumulative abundance was calculated by summing the abundance of all peptides belonged to the respective protein. Proteins were then ranked by p-value (one-way ANOVA) based on the sum of the normalized abundance across all runs.

Total RNA were isolated from different organs (eyes, heart, liver, intestines, muscle, skin, testis, kidney, brain, gill, spleen) of male and female ovary were isolated to test the IQCH expression level in zebrafish (three biological replicates) by using the RNAprep pure Cell/Bacteria kit (TIANGEN), then reverse transcribed into cDNA using the One-Step FastQuant RT Reagent Kit with gDNase (TIAN-GEN). In brief, qPCR assays were performed using the fluorescent dye Power SYBR Green PCR Master Mix and ABI 7500 System. Genespecific primers were designed with the Primer-BLAST (NCBI). Specific primers were designed based on the sequence of the mRNA by NCBI blast primer software. IQCH primer sequence: forward 5 0 -TGCTCCAGAGAGAGGACAGT-3 0 ; reverse 5 0 -CAGAAGCAGCT-GAAGGTGGA-3 0 . To detect function of IQCH in immune system, Â 10^7 CFU/ml E. tarda were injected in medaka fish (Oryzias melastigma). As a comparison, the same volume of PBS was injected into fish. Each group has 4 biological replicates. After 12, 24, 48 h post injection, Total RNA were extracted from testis of infected fish and normal fish. IQCH primer sequence: forward 5 0 -GCTGAAGGGGTCTTTGTCCA -3 0 ; reverse 5 0 -GTGTGGGCGACGTCT-TAGAG-3 0 .

To detect the role of catalase in E. tarda immune system, total RNA were extracted from E. tarda with BHI, serum or heat inactivated serum incubation. Catalase (kat) primer sequence: forward 5 0 -CTCCTTCGAGGTTCTGGAGC-3 0 , reverse 5 0 -ACCGATCAG-CACCGTCATTT-3 0 . 16s rRNA was used as the reference gene to normalize gene expression [47] . The relative expression levels (fold change) of the tested genes were calculated by using the relative expression based on the 2(-Delta Delta C(T)) Method.

The catalase activity of E. tarda with or without 1 h turbot serum incubation was determined using an OxiSelect catalase activity assay kit (catalog number STA-341; Cell Biolabs, Inc.). The reaction was arrested after 1 min and the absorbance was measured at 520 nm. The catalase activity was calculated by standard curve generated with the catalase standard supplied with the kit. The result was expressed as U/mg. One unit of catalase is the amount of enzyme that can decomposed 1 mmole of H 2 O 2 per minute at 25 C.

E. tarda was separately incubated with culture medium (BHI), mM H 2 O 2 and turbot serum (TS) for 30 and 60 min. After multiple washing with PBS, 10 mM 2, 7-Dichlorofluorescin diacetate (DCFH-DA, D6883, Sigma) was added in each experimental group. Images were taken under a fluorescent microscope with excitation 480 nm and emission 520 nm.

All bactericidal assays were performed in triple. Statistical analyses were performed using Prism version 5.02 (GraphPad Software, California). Data are presented as means ± standard errors of values (SD), and statistical significance was determined with one way ANOVA. In all cases, significance was defined as P < 0.05. GO functional categories of identified fish or bacteria proteins were determined by biological process at http://www.uniprot.org/.
